html.p: So far in this course, we have only worked with two vector operations: vector addition and scalar multiplication. In this chapter, we will introduce inner products. The easiest example of an inner product is the dot product in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline].

Definition. If [mathjaxinline]v = \left[ \begin{array}{c} a_1 \\ a_2 \\ \vdots \\ a_ n \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]w = \left[ \begin{array}{c} b_1 \\ b_2 \\ \vdots \\ b_ n \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] are two vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline], we define the dot product of [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline] to be

tr.td: [mathjax]v\dotprod w = a_1b_1 + a_2b_2 + \ldots + a_ nb_ n.[/mathjax]

html.p: Often we will write the dot product as [mathjaxinline]\langle v, w\rangle[/mathjaxinline] instead of [mathjaxinline]v\dotprod w[/mathjaxinline].
